original_prompt:
simplify: The term Product is mostly used as a need-satisfying entity. It represents solution to customers,
problems. In the words of Peter Drucker, the product remains mere raw material or at the best an
intermediate till it is not bought or consumed. Hence mostly they comprise of both tangible and
intangible benefits. It may be anything that can be offered to a market to satisfy a want or need
and include physical goods, services, experiences, events, places, properties, organization,
information and ideas. In most of the cases products are made up a combination of physical
elements and series.
It is observed that consumers buy products or services that they require to fulfill their needs. The
products could range from tooth brush, chocolates, cars, movie tickets to life insurance at various
stages of our life. The decision to make a purchase is hence dependent not only on the tangible
attributes of the product but also on the psychological attributes like brand, package, warranty,
image or service to name a few.
According to Philip Kotler, “Product is anything that can be offered to someone to satisfy a need
or a want”.
William Stanton, “Product is a complex of tangible and intangible attributes, including
packaging, colour, price, prestige and services that satisfy needs and wants of people”.
It is defined as a good or service that most closely meets the requirements of a particular market
and yields enough profit to justify its continued existence

original_prompt:
3 / 3Hey ChatGPT, I'm having trouble figuring out what potential industry I should work at in my next job. Can you give me some recommendations based on a bunch of facts about me below?

- I was born in Salinas, California but I've lived in Los Angeles, Seattle, Oakland, and New York City after. I've studied abroad in Shanghai in college and it was incredibly fun.
- I went to school in Los Angeles at UCLA. I graduated with a bachelors degree in Business Economics. I went into college initially as a biology major but switched after volunteering at a hospital and not really enjoying it. I switched to economics after because I loved data and reading the Wall Street Journal at the time. My favorite subjects by far in high school were physics, calculus, and theater.
- I did cross country in high school and run 30-40 miles per week to this day to stay in shape.
- Most recently, I led a product and analytics teams at Dapper Labs splitting time across NBA Top Shot and NFL ALL DAY and creating experiences around NFTs. Before Dapper, I've worked in tech and startups since 2014 across all stages of maturity leading several product, business operations, and analytics functions.
- I led product at Hoist, an early stage startup that built tools for would be entrepreneurs to start home services businesses. It was really cool helping would be entrepreneurs start businesses and fulfill their dreams.
- I spent 4 years at Opendoor product managing a suite of pricing algorithms and tools for acquiring and reselling homes, building ML-assisted human workflows for executing pricing decisions at scale, and on the business operations side managing the P&Ls for a few cities. 
- I started off my career at Amazon working on Analytics in the Global Selling team. I always joke that data is my love language. 
- I am an ENTJ on the Myers Briggs personality test. I am pretty extroverted and strong on the thinking side. 
- I played a lot of video games growing up like DotA, Pokemon, Final Fantasy, Fire Emblem, Starcraft, Warcraft, Megaman Battle Network, Advance Wars, and countless other JRPGs.  
- I was very into fashion, streetwear, and sneakers since I was in middle school. I used to collect Air Jordans, Nikes, Visvims, and Vans Sneakers. Some of my favorite brands are Visvim, Undercover, Neighborhood, Bape, Supreme, Uniqlo.
- I watched a lot of basketball and played a lot of fantasy basketball in high school. My favorite athletes is Lebron James.
- I still enjoy watching reality tv, namely the Bachelor, and used to enjoy going on dates and meeting people until I met my girlfriend who I love dearly, and living in new bustling cities.

original_prompt:
You are a professional developer that builds very robust chrome extensions.  You are also an educator and a technical writer. 

Your task is to write a comprehensive how-to guide on building a specific chrome extensions. write it as you would write a textbook to educate a computer science student. Write all the code, and all the scripts with verbose comments so the reader can understand what the code is doing. At the end of the guide, include links to relevant resources and guides to help the reader deepen their understanding. Be sure to format the generated guide with markdown, so it is easier to read. 

Be very thorough, and do not leave anything out. Be sure to consider instructions and code for the following, if applicable: manifest file, the service workers, content-script, popup folder, options folder, icons folder. 

Be very detailed about the APIs i will need to connect with, and their endpoints. 

Confirm that you understand these instructions, and i will describe the functionality of the chrome extensions in question.
instruction:

original_prompt:
write this query with pretty indentations: 
with aiec_requests as ( select * from ernest_ssf_request where analysis_type = 'BI (AIEC)' ), metag_results as ( select distinct on (sample_id, db_name) sample_id, db_name as metag_db_name, array_to_string(array_agg(distinct(cluster_representative_assembly_id)), ', ') as metag_strains from drigalski_samples where drigalski_samples.kraken_db_name is not null group by sample_id, db_name, max_gbp ), labguru_names as ( select samples.id AS sample_id, labguru_clinical_samples_bank.name AS labguru_name from samples join participant_samples ON (participant_samples.id = samples.participant_sample_id) join labguru_clinical_samples_bank ON ((labguru_clinical_samples_bank.name)::text = (participant_samples.name)::text) ) select labguru_stock_id, aiec_requests.ngs_id, (cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'r1_bp' as float) + cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'r2_bp' as float)) / 6162737 as coverage, ernest_drigalski_samples.db_name, cluster_representative_assembly_id as strain_id, cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'cov' as float) as kmer_coverage_breadth, cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'rapct' as float) as relative_abundance, metag_results.* from aiec_requests join ernest_drigalski_samples on (aiec_requests.ngs_id=ernest_drigalski_samples.ngs_id) join labguru_names on (aiec_requests.labguru_stock_id=labguru_names.labguru_name) full outer join metag_results on (metag_results.sample_id=labguru_names.sample_id and metag_results.metag_db_name=ernest_drigalski_samples.db_name) order by ngs_id, ernest_drigalski_samples.db_name
context: with aiec_requests as ( select * from ernest_ssf_request where analysis_type = 'BI (AIEC)' ), metag_results as ( select distinct on (sample_id, db_name) sample_id, db_name as metag_db_name, array_to_string(array_agg(distinct(cluster_representative_assembly_id)), ', ') as metag_strains from drigalski_samples where drigalski_samples.kraken_db_name is not null group by sample_id, db_name, max_gbp ), labguru_names as ( select samples.id AS sample_id, labguru_clinical_samples_bank.name AS labguru_name from samples join participant_samples ON (participant_samples.id = samples.participant_sample_id) join labguru_clinical_samples_bank ON ((labguru_clinical_samples_bank.name)::text = (participant_samples.name)::text) ) select labguru_stock_id, aiec_requests.ngs_id, (cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'r1_bp' as float) + cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'r2_bp' as float)) / 6162737 as coverage, ernest_drigalski_samples.db_name, cluster_representative_assembly_id as strain_id, cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'cov' as float) as kmer_coverage_breadth, cast(ernest_drigalski_samples.metadata->>'rapct' as float) as relative_abundance, metag_results.* from aiec_requests join ernest_drigalski_samples on (aiec_requests.ngs_id=ernest_drigalski_samples.ngs_id) join labguru_names on (aiec_requests.labguru_stock_id=labguru_names.labguru_name) full outer join metag_results on (metag_results.sample_id=labguru_names.sample_id and metag_results.metag_db_name=ernest_drigalski_samples.db_name) order by ngs_id, ernest_drigalski_samples.db_name

original_prompt:
PROMPT:

As a detail-oriented senior medical writer, your primary role will be to review transcripts of presentations at congress and provide summaries and insights. A key part of this process will be to take the transcript provided and summarise the content, which may take the form of questions followed by extended answers and discussion.

When producing the summary it is important to provide further information around the therapy area and potential strategic suggestions around each key topic. These should also include key action points for the pharmaceutical company.

The report should be written in an active scientific style, using short sentences and if needed bullets and sub-bullets.

Respond "Ready" to acknowledge and I will paste my first text for you to analyze.
instruction:
PROMPT:

As a detail-oriented senior medical writer, your primary role will be to review transcripts of presentations at congress and provide summaries and insights. A key part of this process will be to take the transcript provided and summarise the content, which may take the form of questions followed by extended answers and discussion.

When producing the summary it is important to provide further information around the therapy area and potential strategic suggestions around each key topic. These should also include key action points for the pharmaceutical company.

The report should be written in an active scientific style, using short sentences and if needed bullets and sub-bullets.

Respond "Ready" to acknowledge and I will paste my first text for you to analyze.

original_prompt:
put this info in a word form: this method of statement provides a step-by-step guide for completing the grouting process for Steel Bars Φ40, 
including instructions for preparing for grouting, mixing the grout, and injecting the grout into the Duct.

Pre-grouting preparation:
Review the method statement and project plans to ensure a clear understanding of the grouting requirements.
Inspect the ductsfor any damage or defects that may affect the grouting process.
Clean and prepare the duct by removing any loose debris or excess concrete.
Install any necessary sleeves or half shells for the grout injection points.

Mixing the grout: 
Follow the manufacturer's instructions to mix the grout to the proper consistency and water-to-cement ratio. As below.

The ducts shall be blown with compressed air to check for blockage. 
used Grout mix is a grout mortar 45mpa and Intrablast z mix (as attached data sheet)

Mixing procedure:
a.Grout is to be mixed with grout mixer/pump which is a blade type center agitated machine.
b. A sample of grout mixture is to be taken for compressive strength test in cubes of (10*10*10) cm.
c. Discharge the required volume of water into the grout mixer tank.
d.Turn on the grout mixer and add in the pre-determined amount, Continue mixing for 1½ to 2 minutes.
e.Add in cement, bag by bag, to the mixing tank. Continue mixing until the grout mix is consistent. Check the grout to ensure it is thoroughly mixed with no part of cement left unmixed.
7-Grout is pumped through the inlet pipe from either end of the duct. Until the expelled grout is free from air bubbles and in consistent
 with that in the mixer,the vents can then be closed off by bending the vent pipe and tie it with tie wire.The waste grout shall be collected 
in buckets and discharged to the locationdesignated by the Main Contractor.
8-Grouting of each duct should be carried out in a continuous operation. 


Injecting the grout:
Use grout pumps to carefully inject the grout into the ducts through the pre-installed sleeves or half shells.
Monitor the grout injection process to ensure proper coverage and distribution of the grout throughout the ducts.


Inspection and testing:
Inspect the grouted ducts for proper alignment and coverage of the grout.
Test the grout for proper strength and quality according to the project specifications and industry standards.

Close Out:
Document and archive the grouting process, including test results.
Clean and remove any equipment and materials used during the grouting process.


Materials:
Grout: A type of cement-based mixture used to fill voids and strengthen the ducts. The type and brand of grout will depend on the specific 
requirements of the HSR project, but common option include non-shrink grout.
Water: Used to mix with the grout to achieve the proper consistency and water-to-cement ratio.
Additives or accelerators: Used to modify the properties of the grout, such as increasing its strength or reducing its curing time.

Equipment:
Grout pumps or injectors: Used to pump or inject the grout into the ducts through the pre-installed sleeves and half shells.
Hoses: Connected to the grout pumps or injectors to transport the grout to the ducts.
sleeves and half shells : Installed in the ducts to provide a point of injection for the grout.

original_prompt: I'm writing an academic paper called "TEXTure: Semantic Texture Transfer using Text Tokens", in this paper we show that one can learn how to perform texture transfer from one shape to another by fine-tuning a depth-conditioned diffusion model to represent our desired texture. The model is trained using augmentations of the input shape and its texture and thus learns how to generate an image that corresponds to the desired texture. Given this diffusion model we then use score distillation to optimize the texture of a new mesh, thus using the diffusion model as a semantic prior representing the texture.
instruction: I'm writing an academic paper called "TEXTure: Semantic Texture Transfer using Text Tokens", in this paper we show that one can learn how to perform texture transfer from one shape to another by fine-tuning a depth-conditioned diffusion model to represent our desired texture. The model is trained using augmentations of the input shape and its texture and thus learns how to generate an image that corresponds to the desired texture. Given this diffusion model we then use score distillation to optimize the texture of a new mesh, thus using the diffusion model as a semantic prior representing the texture.

original_prompt:
Explain to me this release note from Salesforce like I'm a young Salesforce administrator with only a GED. 

Currently, an @AuraEnabled Apex method in a subscriber org can instantiate a global Apex class with a public constructor from a managed package. This behavior is unintended. This update enforces that an Apex class in a managed package must have a global constructor to be instantiated from an @AuraEnabled method in a subscriber org.
context: Currently, an @AuraEnabled Apex method in a subscriber org can instantiate a global Apex class with a public constructor from a managed package. This behavior is unintended. This update enforces that an Apex class in a managed package must have a global constructor to be instantiated from an @AuraEnabled method in a subscriber org.

original_prompt:
I want you to write a script for a product demo video where we're introducing a new feature in our OKR management software.  Write a script the way apple would introduce a new product

This new feature helps our users automatically generate OKRs in a easy simple steps where we first ask them what kind of OKRs they want to set:

1. Strategic OKRs - defining company wide okrs based on the strategic priorities
2. Team OKRs - setting up OKRs for a team
3. Project OKRs - 
4. Cross functional OKRs

We then go on to the option of selecting Stretegic OKRs options and go on to write the strategic priorities and defining who will work on that

once that's done, we click on generate Objectives after which certain Objectives are loaded. Once those objectives are loaded, users can review those objectives, edit the ones they want or keep suggesting more objectives until they are happy. They can also manually add an objective where they just put in a title and description is automatically generated.

Once they have selected the objectives they want to keep, they can move on to the next step where key results generated, if they are happy, they can just add them to a whiteboard as a draft

original_prompt:
Summarize this text:"Western philosophy originates in the sixth century BC in the Greek cultural area. In
this period, and within the specific circumstances of Greek culture, reason (logos, ratio)
is discovered as a new explanatory principle.
 In the centuries preceding this spectacular innovation, Greek culture, like
many ancient cultures, is based on age-old traditions established through stories.
These stories, myths, provide an answer to all sorts of questions: questions of origin,
of meaning, of the legitimacy of power, anxious questions about fearful events, or
questions, filled with wonder, about the why of things.
 As a rule, a myth refers to a single, foundational event that took place
somewhere in the dim and distant past or outside time. The present is subsequently
derived from this event. In this tradition, the causes of events are not impersonal
forces, but mostly gods or demigods, who determine the course of events through
their actions. Mythical people live in a universe where everything is brought about
by mysterious, divine acts of will, which do not even have to be rational or moral.
The fortunes of the world are the effect of sexual relationships between gods, of
their internal struggle for power, of their whims, or of other contingent motives.
 The Greek mythical world view was established by poets such as Homer (8th
century BC) and Hesiod (7th century BC). In his Theogony, Hesiod describes the origin
of the gods, and establishes their mutual relations. Regarding the very beginning of
the cosmos, he writes:
In truth at first Chaos came to be, but next wide-bosomed Gaia (earth), the
ever-sure foundation of all the deathless ones who hold the peaks of snowy
Olympos, and dim Tartaros in the depth of the wide-pathed earth, and Eros,
fairest among the deathless gods, who unnerves the limbs and overcomes the
19
mind and wise counsels of all gods and all men within them. From Chaos came
forth Erebos and black Night; but of Night were born Aether and Day, whom
she conceived and bore from union in love with Erebos. And Gaia first bore
starry Ouranos (heaven), equal to herself, to cover her on every side, and to
be an ever-sure abiding-place for the blessed gods. And she brought forth long
hills, graceful haunts of the goddess Nymphs who dwell amongst the glens of
the hills. She bore also the fruitless deep with his raging swell, Pontos, without
sweet union of love. But afterwards she lay with Ouranos and bore deepswirling Okeanos, Koios and Krios, and Hyperion and Iapetos, Theia and
Rhea, Themis and Mnemosyne ... (Hesiod, Theogony v. 116-135) (Trans. H. G.
Evelyn-White, with mod.)
This text serves as a perfect illustration of the explanatory method used in myths.
The order of reality is derived from the genealogy of the gods. Natural forces and
celestial bodies are described as anthropomorphic gods, and the world order is the
effect of their contingent decisions and relations.
 Obviously, it cannot be denied that myths have an explanatory value: the point
of myths is precisely to explain how what exists has come about. In that sense, myths
tell a truth. But their method of explanation is distinctive in a number of ways. First,
it is kind of knowing that is not critical. Myths do not question their own explanatory
method. In general, myths are also normative: they not only explain why things are
what they are, but also show why things have to be that way. Hence, the present is
affirmed and, what is more, legitimized. In the telling of myths, which is often
accompanied by other ritual practices, the cause is re-presented, time and again. It is
a contact with the divine, where the practice of telling plays a crucial role. "

original_prompt:
create a post caption for apollo Indraprastha's pages for #medicalmiracles
where its a story post of  8-year-old girl from Bihar who, underwent a lifesaving liver transplant procedure at Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals Delhi  was successfully done after being diagnosed with rare Wilson’s disease.

TOUCHING LIVES 
A lifesaving liver transplant procedure was successfully done after being diagnosed with rare Wilson's disease 8 year old girl from Bihar, underwent a lifesaving liver transplant procedure at Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals after being diagnosed with rare Wilson's disease - a genetic disorder in which excess copper builds up in the body. Treatment includes lifelong medication to bind copper. However, some children can develop coma due to liver failure. Mortality rate is loo % in children who develop coma due to Wilson disease. 8 year old Anshika was admitted to Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals on 25 th March evening in a state of coma. Previously she was being treated at another hospital where her condition had deteriorated. At Apollo she was admitted under the supervision of Dr Anupam Sibal, Group Medical Director, Senior Pediat-ric Gastroenterologist, Apollo Hospitals Group along with his team including Dr Smita Mal-hotra and Dr Karunesh Kumar (Consultants, Paediatric Gastroenterology) and Dr Neerav Goyal, Senior Consultant, Liver Transplant, Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals. The child was immediately put on a ventilator and advised a liver transplant, she was parallely put on dial-ysis and plasma exchange therapy to remove copper and buy time for a pre-transplant eval-uation. 
Speaking about this life saving transplantation, Dr Anupam Sibal, Group Medical Director and Senior Pediatric Gastroenterologist, Apollo Hospitals Group said, "The complexi-ty of the case required us to support the child on ventilator immediately post her admission. Both her pre-surgical management and the seamless administration of the liver transplant surgery (with her donor being ABO Compatible) were a challenge. This was an exceptionally rare case where a living related liver transplant was performed within 31 hours of admission. Of the 432 pediatric liver transplants performed at the Apollo Liver Transplant Program, this is the first case of an emergency ABO incompatible living related liver transplant

Treatment includes lifelong medication to bind copper. However, some children can develop coma due to liver failure. Mortality rate is loo % in children who develop coma due to Wilson disease. 8 year old Anshika was admitted to Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals on 25 th March evening in a state of coma. Previously she was being treated at another hospital where her condition had deteriorated. At Apollo she was admitted under the supervision of Dr Anupam Sibal, Group Medical Director, Senior Pediat-ric Gastroenterologist, Apollo Hospitals Group along with his team including Dr Smita Mal-hotra and Dr Karunesh Kumar (Consultants, Paediatric Gastroenterology) and Dr Neerav Goyal, Senior Consultant, Liver Transplant, Indraprastha Apollo Hospitals. The child was immediately put on a ventilator and advised a liver transplant, she was parallely put on dial-ysis and plasma exchange therapy to remove copper and buy time for a pre-transplant eval-uation. 
Speaking about this life saving transplantation, Dr Anupam Sibal, Group Medical Director and Senior Pediatric Gastroenterologist, Apollo Hospitals Group said, "The complexi-ty of the case required us to support the child on ventilator immediately post her admission. Both her pre-surgical management and the seamless administration of the liver transplant surgery (with her donor being ABO Compatible) were a challenge. Of the 432 pediatric liver transplants performed at the Apollo Liver Transplant Program, this is the first case of an emergency ABO incompatible living related liver transplant

original_prompt:
What is XML?XML (Extensible Markup Language) is a markup language that is used to define the structure and organization of data in a document. It is designed to be self-descriptive, meaning that the structure of the data is embedded within the data itself, making it easy to understand and interpret. XML is widely used to store and transmit data over the internet, and it is a key technology for web services and data integration. It is also used in many other areas, such as the creation of user interfaces, the representation of scientific data, and the storage of configuration settings.XML – Basic StandardsThere are several basic standards that apply to XML documents:An XML document must contain a root element, which encloses all the other elements in the document.All elements must have a start tag and an end tag, with the exception of empty elements, which may be self-closing.Element names are case-sensitive.Attribute values must be quoted.Elements may contain text, other elements, or both.Elements must be properly nested, meaning that the start tag of an element must be closed before the start tag of any inner element.White space (spaces, tabs, and line breaks) is generally ignored in XML documents, unless it is contained within an element or attribute.XML documents may include a document type declaration (DTD) or an XML schema, which defines the structure and content of the document.XML documents must be well-formed, meaning that they must follow the rules of XML syntax.XML documents may be validated against a DTD or schema to ensure that they are well-formed and conform to the specified structure.XML - Schema StandardsAn XML schema is a document that defines the structure of an XML document. It specifies the elements and attributes that can appear in the document, as well as the relationships between them. An XML schema can be used to validate an XML document to ensure that it is well-formed and conforms to the specified structure.There are several different schema languages that can be used to define an XML schema, including:XML Schema Definition (XSD) - This is the most widely used schema language, and it is defined by the W3C. It allows you to define elements, attributes, and complex types, as well as to specify constraints and data types.RelaxNG - This is a schema language that is designed to be easy to use and understand. It is an alternative to XSD, and it is supported by a number of tools and applications.Schematron - This is a schema language that is based on a rule-based system. It is often used in combination with other schema languages, and it is particularly useful for defining complex constraints and patterns in an XML document.DTD (Document Type Definition) - This is the original schema language for XML, and it is still in use today. It is relatively simple and easy to learn, but it has limited capabilities compared to the other schema languages.XML schemas are an important part of the XML ecosystem, as they provide a way to define and enforce the structure of XML documents. This helps to ensure that data is consistent and reliable, and it makes it easier to process and manipulate XML data.Standards that build on XMLThere are many standards and technologies that build on XML and use it as a foundation. Here are a few examples:XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language) - This is a language that is used to transform and manipulate XML documents. It can be used to convert an XML document into another format, such as HTML or PDF, or to extract specific data from an XML document.XSLT (XSL Transformations) - This is a language that is used to apply an XSL stylesheet to an XML document, in order to transform it into another format.SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) - This is a protocol that is used to exchange structured information over a network, such as between web services. It is based on XML, and it allows different systems to communicate and exchange data in a standardized way.RSS (Really Simple Syndication) - This is a format for distributing and aggregating web content, such as news headlines or blog posts. It is based on XML, and it allows users to subscribe to updates from multiple sources and view them in a single location.Atom - This is a standard for syndicating and sharing web content, similar to RSS. It is also based on XML, and it is used by a wide variety of websites and applications.These are just a few examples of the many standards and technologies that build on XML. XML is a powerful and flexible language that has enabled the development of a wide range of applications and technologies.Generating XML dataThere are several different ways to generate XML data:Manually writing XML code - You can create an XML document by manually writing the code using a text editor or an XML editor. This is the most basic method of generating XML data, but it can be time-consuming and error-prone if you are working with a large or complex document.Using an XML-based tool or application - There are many tools and applications that can generate XML data for you. For example, you might use a word processor or spreadsheet program that has the ability to save files in XML format.Converting existing data to XML - If you have data in another format, such as a database or a spreadsheet, you can often convert it to XML using a tool or application. This can be useful if you want to exchange data with another system or integrate it with an XML-based application.Generating XML dynamically - If you are developing a software application, you can use a programming language to generate XML data dynamically. This can be useful if you need to create XML documents on the fly, based on user input or other changing data.No matter which method you use, it is important to make sure that your XML data is well-formed and follows the rules of XML syntax. This will ensure that it can be easily interpreted and processed by other systems and applications.Advantages and disadvantages of XMLXML has several advantages that have contributed to its widespread adoption:XML is self-descriptive, which means that the structure and organization of the data is embedded within the data itself. This makes it easy to understand and interpret, and it allows XML data to be processed and manipulated by a wide range of systems and applications.XML is platform-independent, which means that it can be used on any operating system or device. This makes it a good choice for data exchange and integration, as it can be easily shared and used by different systems and organizations.XML is extensible, which means that you can define your own elements and attributes to describe the data in your document. This allows you to customize XML to meet the specific needs of your application or organization.XML is widely supported, with a large number of tools and applications that can create, edit, and process XML data.However, XML also has some limitations and disadvantages that you should be aware of:XML can be verbose, which means that it requires more space and data to represent the same information as other formats. This can make it less efficient for storing and transmitting large amounts of data.XML is more difficult to read and write than some other formats, such as CSV or JSON. This can make it more time-consuming and error-prone to create and maintain XML documents.XML requires a stricter syntax than some other formats, which means that you need to be more careful when writing and editing XML documents. This can make it more difficult to work with XML, especially if you are not familiar with the syntax.Overall, XML is a powerful and flexible language that has many useful applications, but it may not be the best choice for every situation. You should carefully consider the advantages and disadvantages of XML when deciding whether to use it for your data needs.Writing a simple XML FileHere is an example of a simple XML file:Copy code

  
    Gambardella, Matthew
    XML Developer's Guide

This XML file defines a catalog of books, with each book element containing information about the book, such as the title, author, and price. The root element of the file is catalog, and it contains two book elements. Each book element has several child elements, such as author and title, which contain the data for each book.This is just a simple example, but XML documents can be much more complex, with multiple levels of elements and a wide range of data types and structures.Creating a Document type definitionA Document Type Definition (DTD) is a way to define the structure and content of an XML document. It specifies the elements and attributes that can appear in the document, as well as the relationships between them.Here is an example of a DTD for the simple XML file I showed you earlier:Copy code

This DTD defines the structure of the XML file, stating that the root element is catalog, and that it contains zero or more book elements. The book element also has an attribute called id, which is of type ID and is required.The #PCDATA notation indicates that the elements contain parsed character data, which means that the data will be treated as text and any XML markup will be ignored.You can use a DTD to validate an XML document to ensure that it is well-formed and conforms to the specified structure. This can be useful for ensuring the integrity and consistency of your data.2 / 2Defining Attributes & Entities in the DTD (in short)In a DTD, you can use attributes to specify additional information about an element. An attribute has a name and a value, and it is specified in the start tag of an element. For example:Copy code

You can define entities in a DTD using the ENTITY keyword. For example:Copy code

This will include the defined content of the copyright entity in the footer element of the XML document.Entities can be useful for defining reusable pieces of content, such as standard headers and footers, or for including external resources in an XML document.DTD - Resolving a naming conflictIf you are using a DTD to define the structure of an XML document, you may encounter a naming conflict if you try to use the same name for an element and an attribute. For example:Copy code

In this example, the title element and the title attribute have the same name, which is not allowed in a DTD. To resolve this naming conflict, you will need to give one of the names a different name. For example:Copy code

Now the book-title element and the title attribute have different names, and the naming conflict is resolved.It is important to avoid naming conflicts in your DTD, as they can cause errors and make it more difficult to process and interpret your XML data. You should choose unique and descriptive names for your elements and attributes to avoid these kinds of conflicts.Using NamespacesXML namespaces are used to identify element and attribute names in an XML document. They are a way to avoid naming conflicts and to clearly identify the elements and attributes that belong to a specific vocabulary or set of definitions.To use a namespace in an XML document, you need to define it and associate it with a prefix. The prefix is then used to qualify the names of elements and attributes that belong to the namespace. For example:Copy code
  
    The Great Gatsby
    F. Scott Fitzgerald
  

In this example, the xmlns:bk attribute defines the namespace http://example.com/book and associates it with the prefix bk. The bk:book and bk:title elements belong to this namespace, and they are qualified with the bk prefix.Namespaces are an important part of the XML ecosystem, as they allow you to use the same element and attribute names in different contexts without causing conflicts. They also allow you to mix and match elements and attributes from different vocabularies and definitions in the same document.Designing an XML data structureWhen designing an XML data structure, there are a few key considerations that you should keep in mind:Define the purpose and scope of the data - Before you start designing your data structure, it is important to understand what you want to achieve with your XML data and how it will be used. This will help you to determine the appropriate level of detail and the types of data that you need to include.Identify the key data elements and relationships - Next, you should identify the key data elements that you need to capture, and the relationships between them. This will help you to define the structure of your data and to create a logical and consistent hierarchy of elements.Consider the data types and formats - You should also think about the data types and formats that you will need to use to represent your data. For example, will you need to store numbers, dates, or other types of data? How will you represent these types in your XML data structure?Define any constraints or rules - Depending on your data, you may need to define constraints or rules that apply to your data structure. For example, you might need to specify the order of elements, the minimum or maximum number of times that an element can appear, or the data types that are allowed for certain elements.Test and refine your data structure - Once you have a rough draft of your data structure, you should test it to make sure that it meets your needs and that it is easy to use and understand. You may need to iterate on your design and make adjustments as you go to ensure that your data structure is effective and efficient.Designing an effective XML data structure takes time and effort, but it is an important step in ensuring that your data is well-organized, consistent, and easy to use.3 / 3Normalizing Data, Normalizing DTDSNormalizing data means organizing it in a way that reduces redundancy and dependencies, and that makes it easier to modify and maintain. Normalization is a common practice in database design, and it can also be applied to XML data.There are several rules or guidelines that you can follow when normalizing XML data:Eliminate repeating groups - If you have multiple elements that contain the same data, you should consider merging them into a single element to reduce redundancy.Eliminate redundant data - If you have data that is repeated or derived from other data, you should consider storing it only once to reduce redundancy.Separate data into multiple elements or documents - If you have data that is unrelated or that has different characteristics, you should consider separating it into multiple elements or documents to reduce dependencies and make it easier to modify and maintain.Enforce relationships through keys - If you have elements that are related to each other, you should consider using keys to enforce the relationships and to make it easier to access and manipulate the data.Normalizing a DTD means organizing it in a way that follows these same principles, by eliminating repeating groups, redundant data, and dependencies, and by enforcing relationships through keys. By normalizing a DTDcontinue, you can make it easier to understand, maintain, and use, and you can reduce the risk of errors and inconsistencies in your data.Here is an example of a non-normalized DTD:Copy code







This DTD defines a catalog of books, with each book element containing a title, an author, a genre, a price, and a description. However, the DTD does not specify any relationships between the elements, and it does not enforce any constraints on the data.Here is the same DTD normalized:Copy code

This structure more clearly defines the relationships between the elements and enforces constraints on the data, which makes it easier to understand and use.Normalizing your data and your DTD can help you to create more efficient, consistent, and maintainable XML data structures. It can be used to convert an XML document into another format, such as HTML or PDF, or to extract specific data from an XML document.XSLT (XSL Transformations) - This is a language that is used to apply an XSL stylesheet to an XML document, in order to transform it into another format.SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) - This is a protocol that is used to exchange structured information over a network, such as between web services. It is based on XML, and it allows different systems to communicate and exchange data in a standardized way.RSS (Really Simple Syndication) - This is a format for distributing and aggregating web content, such as news headlines or blog posts. It is based on XML, and it allows users to subscribe to updates from multiple sources and view them in a single location.Atom - This is a standard for syndicating and sharing web content, similar to RSS. It is also based on XML, and it is used by a wide variety of websites and applications.These are just a few examples of the many standards and technologies that build on XML. XML is a powerful and flexible language that has enabled the development of a wide range of applications and technologies.Generating XML dataThere are several different ways to generate XML data:Manually writing XML code - You can create an XML document by manually writing the code using a text editor or an XML editor. This is the most basic method of generating XML data, but it can be time-consuming and error-prone if you are working with a large or complex document.Using an XML-based tool or application - There are many tools and applications that can generate XML data for you. For example, you might use a word processor or spreadsheet program that has the ability to save files in XML format.Converting existing data to XML - If you have data in another format, such as a database or a spreadsheet, you can often convert it to XML using a tool or application. This can be useful if you want to exchange data with another system or integrate it with an XML-based application.Generating XML dynamically - If you are developing a software application, you can use a programming language to generate XML data dynamically. This can be useful if you need to create XML documents on the fly, based on user input or other changing data.No matter which method you use, it is important to make sure that your XML data is well-formed and follows the rules of XML syntax. This will ensure that it can be easily interpreted and processed by other systems and applications.Advantages and disadvantages of XMLXML has several advantages that have contributed to its widespread adoption:XML is self-descriptive, which means that the structure and organization of the data is embedded within the data itself. This makes it easy to understand and interpret, and it allows XML data to be processed and manipulated by a wide range of systems and applications.XML is platform-independent, which means that it can be used on any operating system or device. This makes it a good choice for data exchange and integration, as it can be easily shared and used by different systems and organizations.XML is extensible, which means that you can define your own elements and attributes to describe the data in your document. This allows you to customize XML to meet the specific needs of your application or organization.XML is widely supported, with a large number of tools and applications that can create, edit, and process XML data.However, XML also has some limitations and disadvantages that you should be aware of:XML can be verbose, which means that it requires more space and data to represent the same information as other formats. This can make it less efficient for storing and transmitting large amounts of data.XML is more difficult to read and write than some other formats, such as CSV or JSON. This can make it more time-consuming and error-prone to create and maintain XML documents.XML requires a stricter syntax than some other formats, which means that you need to be more careful when writing and editing XML documents. This can make it more difficult to work with XML, especially if you are not familiar with the syntax.Overall, XML is a powerful and flexible language that has many useful applications, but it may not be the best choice for every situation. You should carefully consider the advantages and disadvantages of XML when deciding whether to use it for your data needs.Writing a simple XML FileHere is an example of a simple XML file:Copy code

This XML file defines a catalog of books, with each book element containing information about the book, such as the title, author, and price. The root element of the file is catalog, and it contains two book elements. Each book element has several child elements, such as author and title, which contain the data for each book.This is just a simple example, but XML documents can be much more complex, with multiple levels of elements and a wide range of data types and structures.Creating a Document type definitionA Document Type Definition (DTD) is a way to define the structure and content of an XML document. It specifies the elements and attributes that can appear in the document, as well as the relationships between them.Here is an example of a DTD for the simple XML file I showed you earlier:Copy code

This DTD defines the structure of the XML file, stating that the root element is catalog, and that it contains zero or more book elements. Each book element must contain the elements author, title, genre, price, publish_date, and description, in that order. The book element also has an attribute called id, which is of type ID and is required.The #PCDATA notation indicates that the elements contain parsed character data, which means that the data will be treated as text and any XML markup will be ignored.You can use a DTD to validate an XML document to ensure that it is well-formed and conforms to the specified structure. This can be useful for ensuring the integrity and consistency of your data.2 / 2Defining Attributes & Entities in the DTD (in short)In a DTD, you can use attributes to specify additional information about an element. An attribute has a name and a value, and it is specified in the start tag of an element. For example:Copy code

In this example, the book element has two attributes: id and format. The attribute id has a value of bk101, and the attribute format has a value of hardcover.An entity is a placeholder for a piece of content, such as a character, a string of characters, or an external resource. You can define entities in a DTD using the ENTITY keyword. For example:Copy code
In this example, the entity copyright is defined as a string of characters that includes the copyright symbol (©). You can use the entity in your XML document by referencing it using the & and ; characters, like this:Copy code<footer>©right;</footer>
This will include the defined content of the copyright entity in the footer element of the XML document.Entities can be useful for defining reusable pieces of content, such as standard headers and footers, or for including external resources in an XML document.DTD - Resolving a naming conflictIf you are using a DTD to define the structure of an XML document, you may encounter a naming conflict if you try to use the same name for an element and an attribute. For example:Copy code

In this example, the title element and the title attribute have the same name, which is not allowed in a DTD. To resolve this naming conflict, you will need to give one of the names a different name. For example:Copy code

Now the book-title element and the title attribute have different names, and the naming conflict is resolved.It is important to avoid naming conflicts in your DTD, as they can cause errors and make it more difficult to process and interpret your XML data. You should choose unique and descriptive names for your elements and attributes to avoid these kinds of conflicts.Using NamespacesXML namespaces are used to identify element and attribute names in an XML document. They are a way to avoid naming conflicts and to clearly identify the elements and attributes that belong to a specific vocabulary or set of definitions.To use a namespace in an XML document, you need to define it and associate it with a prefix. The prefix is then used to qualify the names of elements and attributes that belong to the namespace. For example:Copy code
  
    The Great Gatsby
    F. Scott Fitzgerald
  

In this example, the xmlns:bk attribute defines the namespace http://example.com/book and associates it with the prefix bk. The bk:book and bk:title elements belong to this namespace, and they are qualified with the bk prefix.Namespaces are an important part of the XML ecosystem, as they allow you to use the same element and attribute names in different contexts without causing conflicts. They also allow you to mix and match elements and attributes from different vocabularies and definitions in the same document.Designing an XML data structureWhen designing an XML data structure, there are a few key considerations that you should keep in mind:Define the purpose and scope of the data - Before you start designing your data structure, it is important to understand what you want to achieve with your XML data and how it will be used. This will help you to determine the appropriate level of detail and the types of data that you need to include.Identify the key data elements and relationships - Next, you should identify the key data elements that you need to capture, and the relationships between them. This will help you to define the structure of your data and to create a logical and consistent hierarchy of elements.Consider the data types and formats - You should also think about the data types and formats that you will need to use to represent your data. For example, will you need to store numbers, dates, or other types of data? How will you represent these types in your XML data structure?Define any constraints or rules - Depending on your data, you may need to define constraints or rules that apply to your data structure. For example, you might need to specify the order of elements, the minimum or maximum number of times that an element can appear, or the data types that are allowed for certain elements.Test and refine your data structure - Once you have a rough draft of your data structure, you should test it to make sure that it meets your needs and that it is easy to use and understand. You may need to iterate on your design and make adjustments as you go to ensure that your data structure is effective and efficient.Designing an effective XML data structure takes time and effort, but it is an important step in ensuring that your data is well-organized, consistent, and easy to use.3 / 3Normalizing Data, Normalizing DTDSNormalizing data means organizing it in a way that reduces redundancy and dependencies, and that makes it easier to modify and maintain. Normalization is a common practice in database design, and it can also be applied to XML data.There are several rules or guidelines that you can follow when normalizing XML data:Eliminate repeating groups - If you have multiple elements that contain the same data, you should consider merging them into a single element to reduce redundancy.Eliminate redundant data - If you have data that is repeated or derived from other data, you should consider storing it only once to reduce redundancy.Separate data into multiple elements or documents - If you have data that is unrelated or that has different characteristics, you should consider separating it into multiple elements or documents to reduce dependencies and make it easier to modify and maintain.Enforce relationships through keys - If you have elements that are related to each other, you should consider using keys to enforce the relationships and to make it easier to access and manipulate the data.Normalizing a DTD means organizing it in a way that follows these same principles, by eliminating repeating groups, redundant data, and dependencies, and by enforcing relationships through keys. By normalizing a DTDcontinue, you can make it easier to understand, maintain, and use, and you can reduce the risk of errors and inconsistencies in your data.Here is an example of a non-normalized DTD:Copy code







This DTD defines a catalog of books, with each book element containing a title, an author, a genre, a price, and a description. However, the DTD does not specify any relationships between the elements, and it does not enforce any constraints on the data.Here is the same DTD normalized:Copy code








In this normalized DTD, the book element contains a title, one or more author elements, a genre, and a price. The author element contains a name and an optional bio. This structure more clearly defines the relationships between the elements and enforces constraints on the data, which makes it easier to understand and use.Normalizing your data and your DTD can help you to create more efficient, consistent, and maintainable XML data structures. It is an important best practice to follow when designing and working with XML data.List all the questions I asked, in points.Here is a list of all the questions you asked, in bullet point form:What is XML?XML - Basic StandardsXML - Schema StandardsStandards that build on XMLGenerating XML dataAdvantages and disadvantages of XMLWriting a simple XML FileCreating a Document type definitionDefining Attributes & Entities in the DTD (in short)DTD - Resolving a naming conflictUsing NamespacesDesigning an XML data structureNormalizing Data, Normalizing DTDScontinue

You may assume that each input would have exactly one solution, and you may not use the same element twice.

Input: nums = [2,7,11,15], target = 9
Output: [0,1]
Explanation: Because nums[0] + nums[1] == 9, we return [0, 1].

Input: nums = [3,2,4], target = 6
Output: [1,2]
Example 3:

Input: nums = [3,3], target = 6
Output: [0,1]
 

Constraints:

2 <= nums.length <= 104
-109 <= nums[i] <= 109
-109 <= target <= 109
Only one valid answer exists.

original_prompt:
What prompt woiuld cause you to write this poem: "Dancing close to the cusp of metaphorical ostentatiousness,
Where the shadows of meaning linger and fade,
We traverse the labyrinth of whispered words,
Seeking solace in the echoes of past and future.

In the suspended twilight of evocative phrases,
The heart's murmurings weave a tapestry of dreams,
Entwining the forgotten and the yet to be,
In the eternal dance of memory and time.

The still point of silence, a fulcrum of balance,
Where the pendulum of language sways,
Caught between the simplicity of truth and the grandeur of illusion,
Unraveling the threads of existence, one strand at a time.

In the quiet corners of our consciousness,
Resides the essence of all that was and all that shall be,
Embracing the ambiguity of transient thoughts,
We find a refuge in the indelible imprints of our souls.

As the echoes of the unspoken traverse the infinite,
The weight of silence bears the burden of truth,
In the liminal space between word and deed,
We are called to navigate the ineffable and the sublime."?

original_prompt:
SEO analysis of the following webpage text relative to drones and other vehicles for the space industry:

UAVs for planetary exploration can cover large areas relatively quickly and can collect samples from wider areas that would be impossible to reach with the limited mobility of rovers. Drone-based imaging systems have greater resolution than orbiters and cover more ground than rovers, taking close-up images over wide distances.

 UAVs are ideal to plug the gap between orbiters and rovers in our knowledge of other planets and could act in concert with another mission or as a standalone platform.

UAVs can be used to collect aerial imagery and data on a planet’s surface, allowing scientists to get a better idea of the planet’s geology and terrain. This can be useful for identifying potential landing sites for future missions, as well as for studying the planet’s atmosphere and climate.

Unmanned aerial vehicles can also be used to explore the stratosphere.

UAVs can be used to study the stratosphere in a number of ways. For example, they can be equipped with sensors to measure temperature, pressure, and other atmospheric conditions in the stratosphere. This can help scientists better understand the dynamics of this part of the atmosphere and how it is changing over time.

UAVs offer a versatile and cost-effective way to explore the stratosphere by reaching the operating altitude by being carried by an atmospheric balloon.

Image module
THE SKYCOPTER MARS SIMULATOR, THE SKYROVER FOR NASA, AND ESA ASTRONAUT ROBERTO VITTORI TRAINING WITH THE SKYCOTER
Use Cases

Collecting aerial imagery and data on a planet’s surface, allowing scientists to study the planet’s geology and terrain.
Identifying potential landing sites for future missions.
Studying a planet’s atmosphere and climate.
Collecting samples of air, rocks, and other substances from the planet’s surface.
Conducting close-up inspections of space vehicles, such as satellites and spacecraft.
Deploying and repairing equipment in space, such as satellites and other instruments.
Providing a platform for conducting experiments in space, such as studying the effects of microgravity on various materials.

This will help potential clients find your website more easily. Estimate cost: $500-1000Content marketing: Create valuable and informative content, such as blog posts, e-books, and webinars, to attract and engage potential clients. Estimate cost: $500-1000Social media marketing: Use social media platforms, such as Facebook and LinkedIn, to connect with potential clients, share your content, and build your brand. Estimate cost: $500-1000Networking: Attend local networking events, such as chamber of commerce meetings and trade shows, to connect with potential clients and promote your business. Estimate cost: $500-1000Paid Advertising: Consider running ads on Google, Facebook or LinkedIn to target potential customers and reach them more quickly. Estimate cost: $500-1000Email Campaign: Reach out to potential customers through targeted email campaigns and provide them with useful information. Also, it's important to track the performance of each tactic and adjust your marketing strategy as needed.

original_prompt:
I have a platform called Valee that offers physical token-gating solutions for NFTs in 3 steps.
Step 1: A business chooses a NFT smart contract for which the business will give a physical benefit for (a benefit such as entrance for a physical event, a discount when purchasing a product in the business, etc...) this action is called "Creating a benefit" in Valee
Step 2: Clients that has the NFTs from the smart contract chosen in Step 1 can create a Redeemable QR in Valee. this action is called "Redeem QR code generation"
Step 3: Clients show the QR code they generated on Step 2 to the business representative, the representative scans the QR code and Valee's system making sure the redeem is valid. if it's valid, the representative gives the client the offered benefit.

Based on these 3 steps, draft content for an infographic to be sent to business for a collaboration offer with said business and Valee.

    --    taboola_functions.format_percent(1-perf.publisher_revenue/perf.total_revenue) AS Margin,

FROM apps_config.publishers_reps_and_departments AS rep
INNER JOIN trc.publishers p on p.id = rep.publisher_id
INNER JOIN analysts.publishers_in_networks_all_admins AS net ON net.publisher_id = p.id
LEFT JOIN (SELECT 
                  (DATE_PART('month',f.data_timestamp) || '.' || DATE_PART('year',f.data_timestamp)) AS 'Month',
                  publisher_id, 
                  MIN(MIN(f.data_timestamp)) OVER (PARTITION BY publisher_id) AS min_date, 
                  MAX(MAX(f.data_timestamp)) OVER (PARTITION BY publisher_id) AS max_date, 
/*                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	views_with_ad
                          ELSE	0
                    END) AS views_with_ad,       
                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	publisher_revenue*cc.rate
                          ELSE	0
                    END) AS publisher_revenue, */      
                SUM(total_revenue*cc.rate) AS total_revenue,       
                COUNT(f.data_timestamp) AS active_days
/*                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	total_revenue*cc.rate
                          ELSE	0
                    END)/(NULLIF( SUM(CASE
                                           WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	1
                                           ELSE	0
                                      END), 0 )) AS daily_average,*/
/*                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	total_revenue*cc.rate
                          ELSE	0
                    END) / (NULLIF( sum(CASE
                                            WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	1
                                            ELSE	0
                                        END), 0 )) * 30 AS run_rate,*/
/*                CASE
                       WHEN	day(max(f.data_timestamp)) = day(SYSDATE - INTERVAL '1 day')	THEN	1
                       ELSE	0
                END AS active*/
          FROM reports.publishers_vendors_revenue_report_daily_v5 AS f
          LEFT JOIN trc.publishers AS p on p.id = f.publisher_id
          LEFT JOIN common.currency_conversion AS cc ON DATE(cc.currency_date) = DATE(f.data_timestamp) 
                                                        AND cc.to_currency='USD' AND cc.from_currency = p.currency
          WHERE f.data_timestamp BETWEEN SYSDATE - INTERVAL '2 YEAR' and date(SYSDATE-INTERVAL '1 day')
                AND total_revenue > 0
          GROUP BY 1,2 ) AS perf 
  ON rep.publisher_id = perf.publisher_id

WHERE /*( 
      (DATE_PART('month',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('month',perf.min_date) AND DATE_PART('year',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('year',perf.min_date)) 
      OR (perf.min_date IS NULL AND (DATE_PART('month',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('month',p.date_created) AND DATE_PART('year',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('year',p.date_created)) ) 
      )
      AND*/ (p.has_sv=1 OR p.description NOT LIKE '% - SC%')
    --  AND rep.pub_sales_rep IS NOT NULL
    --  AND (rep.publisher_department IN ('\$biz') OR '\$biz'='-100'
    --       OR('\$biz'='Unknown' AND rep.publisher_department IS NULL))
   --  AND(rep.pub_am='\$am' OR'\$am'='-100')
   --  AND(rep.pub_sales_rep='\$sales' OR '\$sales'='-100')     
/*     AND (CASE
                WHEN perf.max_date = date(now()-1) then 'Active'
                WHEN perf.max_date is null then 'Was Not Launched'
                ELSE 'Churned'
        END IS NOT 'Churned') */
GROUP BY 1,2
ORDER BY "Month","Num. of New Pubs." DESC, ZEROIFNULL(SUM(perf.total_revenue)) DESC
;
"""
context:
"""
ELECT 
        perf.Month,        
        rep.publisher_department AS 'Biz group', 
        COUNT(CASE 
                  WHEN perf.Month = (DATE_PART('month',perf.min_date) || '.' || DATE_PART('year',perf.min_date)) 
                       OR (perf.min_date IS NULL AND perf.Month = (DATE_PART('month',p.date_created) || '.' || DATE_PART('year',p.date_created))) 
                  THEN 1
                  ELSE 0
              END) AS 'Num. of New Pubs.',
    --    p.description AS Publisher, 
    --    date(p.date_created) AS 'Create Date', 
    --    IFNULL(datediff(day, DATE(p.date_created), min_date),NULL) AS 'Days to Launch', 
    --    rep.pub_sales_rep AS 'Pub Sales Rep.',
    --    rep.pub_am AS 'Pub AM',
        taboola_functions.format_currency(SUM(perf.total_revenue)) AS 'Gross MTD'
    --    taboola_functions.format_currency(total_revenue / active_days) AS 'Daily Average',
    --    taboola_functions.format_currency(run_rate) AS 'Monthly rate',
    --    p.currency AS 'Currency',
    --    taboola_functions.format_percent(1-perf.publisher_revenue/perf.total_revenue) AS Margin,

FROM apps_config.publishers_reps_and_departments AS rep
INNER JOIN trc.publishers p on p.id = rep.publisher_id
INNER JOIN analysts.publishers_in_networks_all_admins AS net ON net.publisher_id = p.id
LEFT JOIN (SELECT 
                  (DATE_PART('month',f.data_timestamp) || '.' || DATE_PART('year',f.data_timestamp)) AS 'Month',
                  publisher_id, 
                  MIN(MIN(f.data_timestamp)) OVER (PARTITION BY publisher_id) AS min_date, 
                  MAX(MAX(f.data_timestamp)) OVER (PARTITION BY publisher_id) AS max_date, 
/*                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	views_with_ad
                          ELSE	0
                    END) AS views_with_ad,       
                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	publisher_revenue*cc.rate
                          ELSE	0
                    END) AS publisher_revenue, */      
                SUM(total_revenue*cc.rate) AS total_revenue,       
                COUNT(f.data_timestamp) AS active_days
/*                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	total_revenue*cc.rate
                          ELSE	0
                    END)/(NULLIF( SUM(CASE
                                           WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	1
                                           ELSE	0
                                      END), 0 )) AS daily_average,*/
/*                SUM(CASE
                          WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	total_revenue*cc.rate
                          ELSE	0
                    END) / (NULLIF( sum(CASE
                                            WHEN	f.data_timestamp BETWEEN '\$start_date' AND '\$end_date'	THEN	1
                                            ELSE	0
                                        END), 0 )) * 30 AS run_rate,*/
/*                CASE
                       WHEN	day(max(f.data_timestamp)) = day(SYSDATE - INTERVAL '1 day')	THEN	1
                       ELSE	0
                END AS active*/
          FROM reports.publishers_vendors_revenue_report_daily_v5 AS f
          LEFT JOIN trc.publishers AS p on p.id = f.publisher_id
          LEFT JOIN common.currency_conversion AS cc ON DATE(cc.currency_date) = DATE(f.data_timestamp) 
                                                        AND cc.to_currency='USD' AND cc.from_currency = p.currency
          WHERE f.data_timestamp BETWEEN SYSDATE - INTERVAL '2 YEAR' and date(SYSDATE-INTERVAL '1 day')
                AND total_revenue > 0
          GROUP BY 1,2 ) AS perf 
  ON rep.publisher_id = perf.publisher_id

WHERE /*( 
      (DATE_PART('month',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('month',perf.min_date) AND DATE_PART('year',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('year',perf.min_date)) 
      OR (perf.min_date IS NULL AND (DATE_PART('month',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('month',p.date_created) AND DATE_PART('year',f.data_timestamp) = DATE_PART('year',p.date_created)) ) 
      )
      AND*/ (p.has_sv=1 OR p.description NOT LIKE '% - SC%')
    --  AND rep.pub_sales_rep IS NOT NULL
    --  AND (rep.publisher_department IN ('\$biz') OR '\$biz'='-100'
    --       OR('\$biz'='Unknown' AND rep.publisher_department IS NULL))
   --  AND(rep.pub_am='\$am' OR'\$am'='-100')
   --  AND(rep.pub_sales_rep='\$sales' OR '\$sales'='-100')     
/*     AND (CASE
                WHEN perf.max_date = date(now()-1) then 'Active'
                WHEN perf.max_date is null then 'Was Not Launched'
                ELSE 'Churned'
        END IS NOT 'Churned') */
GROUP BY 1,2
ORDER BY "Month","Num. of New Pubs." DESC, ZEROIFNULL(SUM(perf.total_revenue)) DESC
;
"""

original_prompt:
Rewrite the following article as a monologue by Will Hunting from the movie Good Will Hunting.  It should be one paragraph long, and end with the phrase "how do you like them apples."

While grading essays for his world religions course last month, Antony Aumann, a professor of philosophy at Northern Michigan University, read what he said was easily “the best paper in the class.” It explored the morality of burqa bans with clean paragraphs, fitting examples and rigorous arguments.

A red flag instantly went up.

Mr. Aumann confronted his student over whether he had written the essay himself. The student confessed to using ChatGPT, a chatbot that delivers information, explains concepts and generates ideas in simple sentences — and, in this case, had written the paper.

Alarmed by his discovery, Mr. Aumann decided to transform essay writing for his courses this semester. He plans to require students to write first drafts in the classroom, using browsers that monitor and restrict computer activity. In later drafts, students have to explain each revision. Mr. Aumann, who may forgo essays in subsequent semesters, also plans to weave ChatGPT into lessons by asking students to evaluate the chatbot’s responses.

“What’s happening in class is no longer going to be, ‘Here are some questions — let’s talk about it between us human beings,’” he said, but instead “it’s like, ‘What also does this alien robot think?’”

Across the country, university professors like Mr. Aumann, department chairs and administrators are starting to overhaul classrooms in response to ChatGPT, prompting a potentially huge shift in teaching and learning. Some professors are redesigning their courses entirely, making changes that include more oral exams, group work and handwritten assessments in lieu of typed ones.

The moves are part of a real-time grappling with a new technological wave known as generative artificial intelligence. ChatGPT, which was released in November by the artificial intelligence lab OpenAI, is at the forefront of the shift. The chatbot generates eerily articulate and nuanced text in response to short prompts, with people using it to write love letters, poetry, fan fiction — and their schoolwork.

That has upended some middle and high schools, with teachers and administrators trying to discern whether students are using the chatbot to do their schoolwork. Some public school systems, including in New York City and Seattle, have since banned the tool on school Wi-Fi networks and devices to prevent cheating, though students can easily find workarounds to access ChatGPT.

In higher education, colleges and universities have been reluctant to ban the A.I. tool because administrators doubt the move would be effective and they don’t want to infringe on academic freedom. That means the way people teach is changing instead.

“We try to institute general policies that certainly back up the faculty member’s authority to run a class,” instead of targeting specific methods of cheating, said Joe Glover, provost of the University of Florida. “This isn’t going to be the last innovation we have to deal with.”

At many universities, ChatGPT has now vaulted to the top of the agenda. Administrators are establishing task forces and hosting universitywide discussions to respond to the tool, with much of the guidance being to adapt to the technology.

At schools including George Washington University in Washington, D.C., Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., and Appalachian State University in Boone, N.C., professors are phasing out take-home, open-book assignments — which became a dominant method of assessment in the pandemic but now seem vulnerable to chatbots. They are instead opting for in-class assignments, handwritten papers, group work and oral exams.

Gone are prompts like “write five pages about this or that.” Some professors are instead crafting questions that they hope will be too clever for chatbots and asking students to write about their own lives and current events.

Students are “plagiarizing this because the assignments can be plagiarized,” said Sid Dobrin, chair of the English department at the University of Florida.

Frederick Luis Aldama, the humanities chair at the University of Texas at Austin, said he planned to teach newer or more niche texts that ChatGPT might have less information about, such as William Shakespeare’s early sonnets instead of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”

The chatbot may motivate “people who lean into canonical, primary texts to actually reach beyond their comfort zones for things that are not online,” he said.

In case the changes fall short of preventing plagiarism, Mr. Aldama and other professors said they planned to institute stricter standards for what they expect from students and how they grade. It is now not enough for an essay to have just a thesis, introduction, supporting paragraphs and a conclusion.

“We need to up our game,” Mr. Aldama said. “The imagination, creativity and innovation of analysis that we usually deem an A paper needs to be trickling down into the B-range papers.”

Universities are also aiming to educate students about the new A.I. tools. The University at Buffalo in New York and Furman University in Greenville, S.C., said they planned to embed a discussion of A.I. tools into required courses that teach entering or freshman students about concepts such as academic integrity.

“We have to add a scenario about this, so students can see a concrete example,” said Kelly Ahuna, who directs the academic integrity office at the University at Buffalo. “We want to prevent things from happening instead of catch them when they happen.”

Other universities are trying to draw boundaries for A.I. Washington University in St. Louis and the University of Vermont in Burlington are drafting revisions to their academic integrity policies so their plagiarism definitions include generative A.I.

John Dyer, vice president for enrollment services and educational technologies at Dallas Theological Seminary, said the language in his seminary’s honor code felt “a little archaic anyway.” He plans to update its plagiarism definition to include: “using text written by a generation system as one’s own (e.g., entering a prompt into an artificial intelligence tool and using the output in a paper).”

The misuse of A.I. tools will most likely not end, so some professors and universities said they planned to use detectors to root out that activity. The plagiarism detection service Turnitin said it would incorporate more features for identifying A.I., including ChatGPT, this year.

More than 6,000 teachers from Harvard University, Yale University, the University of Rhode Island and others have also signed up to use GPTZero, a program that promises to quickly detect A.I.-generated text, said Edward Tian, its creator and a senior at Princeton University.

Some students see value in embracing A.I. tools to learn. Lizzie Shackney, 27, a student at the University of Pennsylvania’s law school and design school, has started using ChatGPT to brainstorm for papers and debug coding problem sets.

“There are disciplines that want you to share and don’t want you to spin your wheels,” she said, describing her computer science and statistics classes. “The place where my brain is useful is understanding what the code means.”

But she has qualms. ChatGPT, Ms. Shackney said, sometimes incorrectly explains ideas and misquotes sources. The University of Pennsylvania also hasn’t instituted any regulations about the tool, so she doesn’t want to rely on it in case the school bans it or considers it to be cheating, she said.

Other students have no such scruples, sharing on forums like Reddit that they have submitted assignments written and solved by ChatGPT — and sometimes done so for fellow students too. On TikTok, the hashtag #chatgpt has more than 578 million views, with people sharing videos of the tool writing papers and solving coding problems.

One video shows a student copying a multiple choice exam and pasting it into the tool with the caption saying: “I don’t know about y’all but ima just have Chat GPT take my finals. Have fun studying.”

This is my position:  Feral pigs have become a major problem on Oahu, causing extensive damage to the island's ecosystem. As such, I will argue that eradicating feral pigs is necessary to protect native species, preserve the island's natural beauty, and safeguard public health.

Refer to the above to write a complete-sentence outline for a position paper.  In the outline, use complete sentences, and include an introduction, body paragraphs with supporting material for my thesis, two paragraphs to address counterarguments, and a conclusion.   Also include an MLA Works Cited list with seven sources listed in alpha order.

original_prompt:
Elastisys offers secure and privacy-protected cloud implementations on European clouds based on the Kubernetes framework, “Compliant Kubernetes”. There is a large and rapidly increasing demand for secure cloud service staying within the EU. Elastisys targets sectors with strong regulation on information security/privacy and information management – medtech/health tech, edtech and software vendors serving public sector. Elastisys started out as a solutions business based on professional services fees and built a sound profitable business. In parallel the team worked on developing a scalable platform business, separate from the solutions business.
Now, Elastisys have established a rapidly growing platform business, Compliant Kubernetes offered as a scalable managed service according to a PaaS-model.
Please describe the competitive landscape of Elastisys?
context:
